message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of alcohol use disorder and is still in denial. Naltrexone can help reduce alcohol cravings and block the euphoric effects of alcohol, making it a proper medication to use in the management of this patient. Disulfiram should only be used in patients who are fully aware of their alcoholism and the consequences of drinking while taking the medication. Amitriptyline and Topiramate are not indicated for alcohol use disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of alcohol use disorder and drinks more than she initially reports. Naltrexone is used to reduce cravings for alcohol and can be used to manage the patient’s symptoms. Disulfiram is used to create an unpleasant reaction when alcohol is consumed and is not appropriate because the patient still wants to drink. Amitriptyline and Topiramate are not indicated for alcohol use disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has alcohol use disorder, and among the options, only Naltrexone is used to treat this condition by reducing the desire for alcohol. Disulfiram is used as a deterrent to alcohol consumption, Amitriptyline is an antidepressant and Topiramate is an anticonvulsant, none of which are the first-line treatment for alcohol use disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has alcohol use disorder but is still capable of acknowledging the problem and seeking help. Naltrexone is a medication that helps reduce the cravings for alcohol and has been shown to be effective in managing alcohol use disorder. Disulfiram causes an uncomfortable reaction when alcohol is consumed and is used to discourage alcohol consumption, but it may not be appropriate for this patient who drinks moderately. Amitriptyline and Topiramate are not indicated for alcohol use disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient exhibits symptoms of alcohol use disorder and would benefit from medication-assisted treatment with naltrexone, which reduces the craving and rewarding effects of alcohol. Disulfiram is used to create unpleasant reactions if alcohol is consumed, which may not be suitable for this patient. Amitriptyline and topiramate have not been shown to be effective for alcohol use disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is presenting symptoms of alcohol dependence and is in denial of the issue. Naltrexone is used to help reduce alcohol cravings and dependence, while Disulfiram is used to deter patients from drinking by causing an unpleasant reaction. Amitriptyline and Topiramate are not commonly used for alcohol dependence.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of alcohol dependence and it is recommended to use Naltrexone to reduce cravings and dependence on alcohol. Disulfiram is also an option, but it induces a negative reaction to alcohol, which may not be suitable for all patients. Amitriptyline and Topiramate are not commonly used for alcohol dependence treatment.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s drinking patterns indicate alcohol use disorder, and Naltrexone can help reduce alcohol cravings and the desire to drink. Disulfiram is used as an aversion therapy, and Amitriptyline and Topiramate have no indication for alcohol use disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest alcohol use disorder, and among the options, Naltrexone is used to reduce cravings for alcohol and can be part of the management plan for this patient. Disulfiram is used to create a negative reaction to alcohol, and Amitriptyline and Topiramate are not used specifically for alcohol use disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has alcohol use disorder and needs appropriate medication to help with her symptoms. Naltrexone can reduce alcohol cravings and help with relapse prevention by blocking the pleasurable effects of alcohol. Disulfiram, on the other hand, causes unpleasant effects when alcohol is consumed, and may not be suitable for the patient who wants to continue moderate drinking. Amitriptyline and Topiramate are not commonly used in the treatment of alcohol use disorder.
